ai-ud4.1:1.2_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling near Cālikā, on the Cālikā mountain.
ai-ud4.1:1.3_0: Then at that time venerable Meghiya was the Fortunate One’s attendant.
ai-ud4.1:1.4_0: Then venerable Meghiya went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud4.1:1.4_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-ud4.1:1.5_0: While stood on one side venerable Meghiya said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud4.1:1.6_0: “Reverend Sir, I want to enter Jantugāma for alms.”
ai-ud4.1:2.1_0: Then Meghiya robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Jantu village for alms.
ai-ud4.1:2.2_0: After the meal, on his return from alms-round in Jantu village, he went to the shore of Kimikālā river.
ai-ud4.1:2.3_0: As he was going for a walk along the shore of the river he saw a lovely and delightful mango grove.
ai-ud4.1:2.4_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud4.1:2.5_0: “Oh, this mango grove is lovely and delightful! It’s truly good enough for meditation for a kinsman who wants to meditate.
ai-ud4.1:2.6_0: This is good enough for a gentleman who wishes to put forth effort in meditation.
ai-ud4.1:2.7_0: If the Buddha allows me, I’ll come back to this mango grove to meditate.”
ai-ud4.1:3.1_0: Then venerable Meghiya went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud4.1:3.2_0: While sat on one side venerable Meghiya said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud4.1:4.1_0: “Here I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Jantu village for alms.
ai-ud4.1:4.2_0: After the meal, on his return from alms-round in Jantu village, he went to the shore of Kimikālā river.
ai-ud4.1:4.3_0: I saw a lovely and delightful mango grove.
ai-ud4.1:4.5_0: ‘Oh, this mango grove is lovely and delightful! It’s truly good enough for meditation for a kinsman who wants to meditate.
ai-ud4.1:4.6_0: This is good enough for a gentleman who wishes to put forth effort in meditation.
ai-ud4.1:4.7_0: If the Buddha allows me, I’ll come back to this mango grove to meditate.’
ai-ud4.1:4.8_0: “If the Buddha allows me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
ai-ud4.1:5.1_0: When that was said, the Fortunate One said this to venerable Meghiya:
ai-ud4.1:5.2_0: “We’re alone, Meghiya. Wait until another mendicant comes.”
ai-ud4.1:6.1_0: For a second time Meghiya said to the Buddha,
ai-ud4.1:6.2_0: “Sir, the Buddha has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
ai-ud4.1:6.4_0: If you allow me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
ai-ud4.1:6.5_0: For a second time the Buddha said,
ai-ud4.1:6.6_0: “We’re alone, Meghiya. Wait until another mendicant comes.”
ai-ud4.1:7.1_0: For a third time venerable Meghiya said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud4.1:7.2_0: “Sir, the Buddha has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
ai-ud4.1:7.4_0: If you allow me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
ai-ud4.1:7.5_0: “When you are talking about striving, Meghiya, what can we say?
ai-ud4.1:7.6_0: Please, Meghiya, go at your convenience.”
ai-ud4.1:8.1_0: Then Venerable Meghiya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went to that mango grove,
ai-ud4.1:8.1_1: and after going, and sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-ud4.1:8.2_0: But while Meghiya was meditating in that mango grove he was beset mostly by three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts, namely,
ai-ud4.1:9.3_0: I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith,
ai-ud4.1:9.4_0: should then be ensnared by these three bad, unwholesome thoughts, namely,
ai-ud4.1:10.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Meghiya came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-ud4.1:10.2_0: While sat on one side venerable Meghiya said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud4.1:10.3_0: “Sir, while I was in that mango grove I was beset mostly by three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts, namely,
ai-ud4.1:10.7_0: I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith,
ai-ud4.1:10.8_0: should then be ensnared by these three bad, unwholesome thoughts, namely,
ai-ud4.1:11.1_0: “Meghiya, when the heart’s release is not ripe, five things help it ripen.
ai-ud4.1:12.1_0: Firstly, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
ai-ud4.1:13.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-ud4.1:14.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. It leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-ud4.1:14.2_0: talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-ud4.1:14.3_0: Such talk as this he gains as he desires, he gains without difficulty, gains without trouble.
ai-ud4.1:15.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
ai-ud4.1:16.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
ai-ud4.1:16.3_0: These are the five things that, when the heart’s release is not ripe, help it ripen.
ai-ud4.1:17.1_0: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be ethical ...
ai-ud4.1:18.1_0: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart ...
ai-ud4.1:18.2_0: talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-ud4.1:18.3_0: Such talk as this he gains as he desires, he gains without difficulty, gains without trouble.
ai-ud4.1:19.1_0: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be energetic ...
ai-ud4.1:20.1_0: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be wise ...
ai-ud4.1:21.1_0: But then, a mendicant grounded on these five things should develop four further things.
ai-ud4.1:21.2_0: You should develop the perception of ugliness to give up greed, love to give up malicious thoughts, and mindfulness of breathing to give up cruel thoughts.
ai-ud4.1:21.3_0: When you perceive impermanence, the perception of not-self becomes stabilized. Perceiving not-self, you uproot the conceit ‘I am’ and attain extinguishment in this very life.”
ai-ud4.1:22.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud4.1:23.3_0: Not understanding these thoughts in the mind,
ai-ud4.1:23.4_0: one with mind astray runs all over the place.
ai-ud4.1:24.1_0: Having understood these thoughts in the mind,
ai-ud4.1:24.2_0: an awakened one—keen, restrained, and mindful—
ai-ud4.1:24.3_0: that has arisen in the mind-made.
